awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 1: A transdisciplinary approach to next-gen natural hazard modeling: Improving accuracy and usability of earth surface process models for pre-event risk assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
Natural hazards impact thousands of people every year; floods, droughts, extreme storms, landslides, wildfires, and permafrost erosion all change the Earth's surface and inflict tremendous damage to human infrastructure. Most often, humans respond to disasters "after the fact" and a paradigm shift is needed to a strategy of resilience that would provide a way to reduce vulnerability to disasters and their impacts before they occur. This workshop will focus disparate efforts in natural hazard modeling in the earth surface processes towards a common goal of modeling for risk assessment. A resulting white paper will provide policy makers, funding agencies, and the science community with a clear agenda and timeline on needs for improving modeling fundamentals, and needs for modeling cyberinfrastructure and model-data couplings and high performance computing capability as needed to inform natural hazard occurrence. 

This workshop aims at bringing in a diverse group of scientists and students across career stages to work towards the problem of natural hazard modeling. The workshop will build on the momentum of several existing modeling and data communities; Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System, EarthCube, and Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure DesignSafe. The organizers will bring together leading representatives of these initiatives for keynotes, clinics and extensive break-out discussions. Explicitly, they will aim for inclusivity by striving for gender balance in keynotes and clinic leaders, and make a dedicated effort to bring students from underrepresented groups through a Student Modeler Award competition and several diversity stipends.

por.por_cntn:
Natural hazards cause thousands of deaths and inflict tremendous societal damage. The database of the United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction shows that the US alone experienced 212 disasters between 2005-2014, worth $443 billion dollars in damage. Hurricane Harvey being a striking example in 2017 of one of the costliest events. However, this is a global issue; worldwide over that same period, 700,000 people were killed and 1.7 billion people were affected by disasters. As a priority for action, the United Nations and the US National Academy urged a fundamental switch from merely responding to disasters after the fact, to a proactive strategy of planning and building resilience to reduce vulnerability to disasters before they occur.

 

Computational modeling provides an essential tool to better understand the fundamental surface processes causing natural hazards and their impact on earth's surface change, especially where observations might fall short. And often this is the case; observations may not be available because of difficult observing conditions during extreme events, or only sparse datasets are available to work with since extreme events are rare. Models do not necessarily suffer these shortcomings, and thus can contribute to quantitative pre-event risk assessments through scenario modeling. Yet such assessments are only appropriate if models capture the important physical processes, are tested and well-vetted, and when proven accurate.

 

To further explore and promote model-driven risk assessments, the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System (CSDMS) organized a workshop on Geoprocesses & Geohazards with support from U.S. National Science Foundation ?Prediction of and Resilience against Extreme Events (PREEVENTS)? program, and the EarthCube program. An international interdisciplinary group of over 130 scientists met for 3 days to assess and discuss the state of knowledge in natural hazard modeling for risk assessment, focusing on building a next-generation cyberinfrastructure and a community for modeling practices.

Workshop information, materials and presentations are made available for anyone to watch and download: https://csdms.colorado.edu/wiki/CSDMS_meeting_2018

A summary report to the broad geoscience community was published as a news article in EOS Earth & Space Science News. More detailed scientific advances in model driven risk assessments are to be published in a special issue ?Advances in computational modelling of natural hazards and geohazards? in the open-access Copernicus journal Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences (NHESS). This special issue was advertised widely beyond the workshop participants and received several submissions that are now in advanced stages of manuscript peer-review.

 

This project set an agenda for future efforts in pre-event risk assessment modeling and identified four main gaps to be addressed:

  • The need to better integrate extreme events in earth surface modeling. Low probability, high magnitude events often dictate landscape forms, and have the potential to reset the directionality for long-term change. However, models might not run on spatial or time scales that capture such a hazard. Or models do capture certain processes like flooding, but do not model the associated morphological changes.
  • The need for cyberinfrastructure to better integrate multiple models and data, because cascading natural hazards are a common phenomena. Although many single-hazard models exist, almost none are capable of integrating across hazards, which is a necessity to truly assess risk. Coupling frameworks can accommodate for this, and need to be better generalized, advertised, tested and adopted.
  • The importance of interdisciplinary research. Modeling the evolution of landscapes for risk assessment critically requires incorporating human dynamics. Human actions can trigger or magnify natural hazards in an evolving landscape.  There is value therefore in having the human factor integrated in or coupled to environmental models.
  • The need for developing strategies for model testing, model validation, and model benchmarking against natural disasters as they happen, and, with the recent explosion in remote-sensing data acquisition, rapidly afterwards. This practice would provide insight into model uncertainty and to what extent models can be implemented towards solving applied problems.

 

A white paper resulting from this project is to benefit policy makers and funding agencies as well as the science community explaining further this agenda for improving modeling fundamentals, needs for modeling cyberinfrastructure and model-data couplings as needed to inform natural hazard occurrence.

Modified by: Albert J Kettner
